explanation: Key answers for configuring Git installations, identity, credential storage, and signing.

answerKey.rationale: `git --version` confirms Git is installed and accessible on PATH.
Official package sources and checksum validation maintain secure, patched installations.
Global scope writes to ~/.gitconfig for the current user.
user.name and user.email establish authorship metadata applied to future commits.
SSH keys enable secure, passwordless authentication to remotes.
Local, global, and worktree config files contribute to effective Git settings.
core.editor chooses the program invoked for interactive message editing.
credential.helper manager-core integrates with secure OS credential storage.
core.autocrlf mitigates CRLF/LF differences on Windows when collaborating cross-platform.
Signed commits require generated keys, configuration, and publishing the public key.
git config --get reads the merged value of a key from all scopes.

keyPoints: Use trusted package managers and digital signatures for binaries.
Global config stores identity for all repositories.
SSH and credential helpers provide secure remote authentication.
core.editor and core.autocrlf tailor Git's behavior to your OS.
Signed commits require key management and host integration.
Git merges settings from system, global, local, and worktree scopes.
Credential helpers avoid storing passwords in plain text.
Line-ending configuration reduces noisy diffs in cross-platform teams.
Regularly audit git config values to maintain secure defaults.
